summary.body: Dear All, I do not know if you have received the letter from the estate office about the Garchey. Practically we have to vote about the removal. I am in favour of the removal because the garchey is a polluting system of disposal: I invite the people who oppose this to look at the functioning:just google garchey+ Corporation - [b]the rubbish is treated twice with polluting agents such as thick bleach which is  very polluting plus the chemicals you use to keep the monster clean.[/b] What I oppose is the fact that I have to pay again for the removal when I ahve already paid for it , the average cost for the removal of the syphon is about 500 pounds which I will be happy to spend on a romantic week end but not for the Corporation. I am willing to pay for the removal of the pipes and parts in common but not for the syphon etc in my flat. [u]I propose to write yes to the removal but not willing to pay for the removal of the syphon as already removed[/u] I am already paying for a service that i do not receive I mean I pay for people to use it 110 pounds and I think this is enough in terms of contribution for the community. So I invite the people who support this to form a lobby or write directly to the Corporation. Union makes strength as we say in Italian.[b]   [/b]
summary.subject: Garchey! We have to vote...

summary.body: With the new rules in it seems that the local pubs are all applying for late licenses.  I gather this doesn't mean they will necessarily open late but it does mean if they get them they will have the freedom to do so. Under the new rules once they have this licence they have it forever - there is no annual renewal process. The Pubs involved are: The Podium - 12.30 am The Hoggs Head (Aldersgate Street) - 2.00 am The Rack and Tenter (Love Lane/Citypoint) - 2.30 The Globe (Moorgate) - 2 am The Cuban Bar (City Point) - 1  am Objections are due either this weekend or next - send them to the David Milnes at the the town clerk's department -   Include your name and address in the email.
summary.subject: 5 New late night license applications

summary.body: When Somerfield acquired 115 stores from Morrisons, the Office of Fair Trading referred the matter to the Competition Commission.  The Competition Commission has this morning issued its provisional findings. It believes that there are competition concerns in 14 of the areas. These are listed, but do not include Whitecross Street. This surprised me as Somerfield seems to have our local market thoroughly stitched up (particularly on Sundays). If only Somerfield were required to sell on the Whitecross Street store to another operator...  Anyone wishing to comment on the findings is invited to e-mail  . A summary of the provisional findings report is available on
summary.subject: Calling all anti-Somerfield campaigners

summary.body: Please register your dissatisfaction with the St Alphage House redevelopment proposals by signing the   today. We have already collected several hundred signatures in the paper version and are now supplementing this with an online version. We welcome signatures from anyone who cares about the Barbican, whether you live here, work in the area, have some other connection with the Barbican or even none at all.  If you have already signed the paper version, we ask you not to sign again online, as we can only count you once - no matter how strongly you feel. Please ask you neighbours, your friends, or anyone else you know who cares about the Barbican to consider signing too.  Our group is a sub-group of the Barbican Association, and we have been given the task to make explicit residents' strong objections to what has been proposed. We are currently engaged in extensive research so that when the scheme comes to planning, we will be able to make the strongest case for why the scheme should be refused. We will soon have more information and will do our best to keep you informed through this site, through the  , and for Barbican residents, through the BA Newsletter delivered to your letterbox. Tim Macer Chair, Barbican Association St Alphage House Group Tel. (020) 3291 2938
summary.subject: St Alphage House petition - now open online

summary.body: Have spent an hour this evening looking at the proposals for the redevelopment of Milton Court and am extremely worried.  There was no mention, that I could see, of the impact a 42 storey building would have on the surrounding residential buildings.  In the expensive looking mock ups of every possible aspect of the new building + model, there was no reference to Cromwell Tower for example.  Residents there, and their current views had been conveniently forgotten. There was also minimal reference to Speed House & Willoughby House, unless I am mistaken. Am I the only one concerned about the imposing nature of the building, the impending building noise, light disturbance and additional hassle such a large building will cause? When I asked the City of London representative about the impending planning application & the date it would be submitted, he was reluctant to be specific.  He tried to placate me with "sometime in June".  My advice to all residents in the Barbican is to be vigilant about the planning applications and register your objections as soon as possible.  I would be interested in other peoples opinions on the redevelopment plans.....
summary.subject: Milton Court - proposed redevelopment
